content.content: Why Do We Need APIs for Web UI Components?
APIs (Application Programming Interfaces) are critical for modern web UI components because they:
Enable Customization: Developers can tailor components to match application requirements without altering the core code.
Clear APIs separate logic from presentation, making updates and debugging easier.
APIs allow components to interact seamlessly with other parts of the application or external services.
Predefined properties, methods, and events reduce development time by providing ready-to-use functionality.
APIs in UI components typically expose properties and methods
Properties define the state or configuration of the component.
Enable or disable persisting component‚Äôs state between page reloads.
Methods perform actions on the component dynamically.
Retrieve JSON data content from the editor.
Welcome to the Block Editor Demo!
! This demo highlights all supported block types and inline formatting options. Each section below explains the purpose of the block and shows how it appears in the editor.
Paragraph blocks are used for writing regular text. They are the most common block type and support inline formatting to enhance readability and emphasis.
to indicate removals or outdated text.
O - with superscript and subscript. Add inline code
Table blocks organize data in rows and columns for easy comparison or presentation. They support headers and basic styling
Image blocks allow you to insert visuals to support or enhance your content.
Checklists help track tasks or steps:
Headings help organize content into sections. Use different levels
Use quote blocks to emphasize important statements or references.
‚ÄúQuotes are perfect for highlighting key messages or testimonials.‚Äù
Callouts are great for tips, warnings, or notes that need attention.
command to quickly insert blocks like headings, lists, or code.
Use code blocks to display syntax-highlighted code snippets for technical documentation or tutorials.
Toggle blocks are interactive and help manage long or optional content.
This is a toggle block. You can hide or show content as needed. Useful for FAQs or detailed sections.
Dividers are horizontal lines used to separate sections or indicate a break in content.

The Block Editor provides a comprehensive event system that allows developers to track user interactions and customize workflows. Events are essential for implementing real-time updates, analytics, and advanced features.
Monitor block-level actions for better control.
Use events wisely ‚Äî avoid unnecessary listeners to maintain optimal performance.
Detect when blocks are added, removed, transformed or updated.
Track active blocks when the editor gains focus.
Event usage in the Block Editor
Trigger blockChanged to save content periodically.
Sync changes in real-time using blockChanged.
Cases to avoid when binding events
Binding heavy logic to blockChanged without debouncing can cause performance issues.
Adding multiple listeners for the same event can lead to memory leaks and unexpected behavior.
Avoid binding events that are not relevant to your workflow.
Heavy DOM manipulation or API calls inside frequent events can degrade the user experience.
Use debouncing for frequent events like blockChanged.
Remove listeners when they are no longer needed.
Keep event callbacks lightweight and efficient.
Combine events for analytics without impacting UX.
‚ÄúEvery interaction tells a story ‚Äî listen carefully.‚Äù

Pasting content from external sources often introduces unwanted styles and inconsistent formatting. The Block Editor provides a powerful cleanup mechanism with customization options to maintain consistency and security.
Removes inline styles for cleaner markup.
Preserves semantic structure like headings and paragraphs.
Converts rich text into clean blocks for easy editing.
Extracts links and mentions without clutter.
You can configure paste cleanup behavior using the following settings:
Hooks for before and after paste actions:
Strips all styles and converts to plain text.
Use paste cleanup to remove inline styles while retaining semantic structure.

Add an inspiring or strategic quote here to set the tone.
Clearly state the user/business problem, why it matters now, and the value or impact of solving it.
Define the measurable outcomes we want to achieve.

content.content: The agenda outlines the topics to be discussed and ensures the meeting stays focused and productive. Each item should have a clear purpose and expected outcome.
‚Äì Brief introduction and purpose of the meeting.
‚Äì Key issues or decisions to address.
‚Äì Summarize decisions and assign new tasks.
Use this section to capture additional details, observations, or important remarks that do not fall under specific agenda items.
